{
  "article_text": [
    "we study a class of knots generalizing torus knots , which we call _ lissajous - toric _ :",
    "a torus knot is generated by a a circle rotating around an axis and a lissajous - toric knot is generated by a lissajous curve rotating around the axis .",
    "there are several ways of describing them .",
    "we recall the description of the @xmath0-torus knot in @xmath1 endowed with an orthonormal frame @xmath11 ( see for exemple [ cr ] 1.5 ) . if @xmath12 is the circle of radius @xmath13 centered at @xmath14 in the @xmath15 plane , a point travelling along the knot goes @xmath2 times around @xmath12 while @xmath12 is rotated @xmath3 times around the axis @xmath16 .",
    "+ in the case of the _ lissajous - toric knots _ , we replace the vertical circle by a vertical lissajous curve : we take three integers @xmath17 with @xmath18 and a real number @xmath19 , and we define a knot @xmath20 as follows .",
    "consider the curve @xmath21 given in a vertical plane by @xmath22\\longrightarrow\\mathbb{r}^3\\ ] ] @xmath23 and rotate @xmath21 is rotated @xmath3 times around the axis generated by @xmath24 . in cartesian coordinates , we write the knot as @xmath25      we write ( * ) above in cylindrical coordinates : @xmath27 thus @xmath20 is a closed @xmath3-braid which we can write in the @xmath26-cylinder @xmath28 as follows : @xmath29 note the similarity with the @xmath0-torus knot which is written in the @xmath26-sphere or the @xmath26-cylinder as @xmath30      just as billiard curves are equivalent to lissajous knots ( cf .",
    "[ jp ] ) lissajous toric knots are equivalent to billiard curves in a square solid torus , namely a cube where the top and bottom have been identified ; c. lamm introduced them in [ la 1 ] , see also the related [ l - o ] .",
    "such billiard curves are parametrized similarly to lissajous toric knots ; the trigonometric functions are replaced by _ saw - tooth functions _ of the type @xmath31-\\frac{1}{2}|.$ ] and @xmath32 $ ] .",
    "@xmath33   & \\longrightarrow [ -1,1]^3 \\\\                     t & \\mapsto    \\left ( g(n.t ) , g(p.t+\\phi ) , h(q.t ) \\right )             \\end{array }          \\right)\\ ] ]    c. lamm noticed that these billiard curves in a solid torus do not depend on the phase up to mirror transformation and stated that , if @xmath34 and @xmath2 are mutually prime , the knot @xmath4 is ribbon .",
    "+      we first encountered the @xmath20 s in [ s - v ] when we studied the singularities of minimal disks in @xmath35 ; having noticed that their knot types do not depend on the phase @xmath19 up to mirror transformation , we dropped the @xmath19 in the notation .",
    "+ we consider a minimal , i.e. conformal harmonic , map @xmath36 where @xmath37 is the unit disk in @xmath38 , with @xmath39 , i.e. @xmath40 has a branch point at @xmath41 .",
    "if moreover @xmath40 is a topological embedding , we can copy milnor s construction of algebraic knots ( [ mi ] ) and take the intersection of @xmath42 with a small sphere centered at @xmath43 : we obtain a _ minimal knot_. complex curves are a special case of minimal surfaces and the germ @xmath44 yields the @xmath0-torus knot . in [ s - v ]",
    "the knots @xmath20 s came from germs of singularities of the type @xmath45 with @xmath46 in [ s - v ] we called the @xmath4 s _ simple minimal knots _ ; in the present paper we drop the assumption ( [ hypothese riemannienne ] ) and study these knots _ per se _ ; _ lissajous - toric _ is a more appropriate name for the general case .      in [ s - v ]",
    "we defined a braid @xmath6 naturally associated to the knot @xmath4 ; we describe it here in much greater detail .",
    "we view @xmath6 as a collection of graphs of @xmath3 functions from @xmath47 $ ] to @xmath48 ; the purpose of the small positive number @xmath49 is to avoid crossing points at the endpoints of the interval .",
    "we prove in  [ preuve de la proposition sur les tresses periodiques ] below    [ ce qui nous mene a lassumption ] let @xmath50 , @xmath51 , @xmath52 ; then @xmath53    since @xmath54 and @xmath55 are mutually prime and since the knot type does not change if we interchange @xmath34 and @xmath2 , we make the    [ assumption on the integers ] the numbers @xmath34 and @xmath2 are mutually prime and @xmath2 is odd .    in  [ paragraph - description of the simple minimal braid ] , we construct two braids @xmath56 and @xmath57 of the form @xmath58 where the @xmath59 s are the standard generators of the braid group @xmath60 and the exponents @xmath61 of the @xmath59 s appearing in @xmath62 and @xmath63 are given by simple formulae in @xmath17 .",
    "+   + we will state below the main theorem which expresses the braid @xmath6 as a product of the braids @xmath56 , @xmath64 , @xmath57 and @xmath65 as follows : @xmath66 where the @xmath3-braid @xmath67 is also a product of @xmath68 s and @xmath69 s .",
    "we illustrate the main theorem in ",
    "[ section sur les exemples ] by going through the examples we gave in [ s - v ] and we prove it in  [ the structure of a simple minimal braid : proofs ] .",
    "+ in the rest of the paper , we drop the assumption [ assumption on the integers ] and study the topology of the knot . in  [ preliminaires sur le ribbon ] , we prove a theorem stated by lamm    [ theoreme sur le ribbon ]    if @xmath34 and @xmath2 are mutually prime , the knot @xmath4 is ribbon .",
    "[ corollaire sur les noeuds periodiques ] if @xmath70 , the knot @xmath4 is periodic and its braid is the @xmath9-th power of a braid which closes in a ribbon knot .",
    "[ theoreme sur le four - genus ] if @xmath50 , the four - genus of @xmath4 verifies @xmath71    the right - hand side of ( [ inegalite pour le four genus ] ) is the genus of the @xmath72-torus knot ( cf .",
    "[ k - m ] ) .",
    "the inequality ( [ inegalite pour le four genus ] ) can be strict : for example the knot @xmath73 is @xmath74 which is slice .",
    "there is one case where we know that ( [ inegalite pour le four genus ] ) is an equality :    [ four genus ; egalite ] let @xmath17 be positive integers with @xmath18 , @xmath75 and let @xmath76 @xmath77 the knot @xmath4 is represented by a quasipositive braid and its @xmath10-genus is @xmath78    finally , replacing @xmath79 by @xmath80 in the expression of @xmath4 given in  [ a description in r3 ] yields    if @xmath34 and @xmath2 have different parities ( and thus @xmath3 is odd ) , then @xmath4 is preserved by the involution @xmath81 hence it is positive strongly amphicheiral .",
    "some of the @xmath4 s are actually trivial knots ; in  [ la section sur les noeuds triviaux ] show :    [ liste de noeuds triviaux ] if @xmath3 and @xmath2 are mutually prime , the knots @xmath82 , @xmath83 , @xmath84 and @xmath85 are trivial .",
    "can we get all the trivial @xmath4 s this way ?",
    "we did computer simulations using the braid software from the liverpool knot group ( [ br ] ) and knotplot ( [ kp ] ) : they told us that in some cases ( the @xmath86 s for example ) the answer is yes but in most cases the answer is no ( see the lists of jones polynomials at the end of the paper ) .",
    "we are grateful to moshe cohen whose stimulating conversation prompted us to embark on this work .",
    "here is an informal description of the contents of the main theorem .",
    "+   + there are @xmath87 values of @xmath79 in @xmath88 $ ] ( we call them _ crossing values _ ) above which two or more of the @xmath3 graphs forming @xmath6 meet ( at _ crossing points _ ) and the data of all these crossing points make up the braid ( see figure [ premiere image de tresse ] ) ; above each of the crossing values @xmath79 s , the generators of the braid group @xmath60 describing the corresponding crossing points are all even ( i.e. of the form @xmath89 ) or all odd ( i.e. of the form @xmath90 ) .",

    "we settle the case of the @xmath96 s with @xmath323 by noticing that @xmath324",
    "a _ ribbon knot _ in @xmath325 bounds a disk in @xmath325 with only ribbon singularities ; equivalently it bounds an embedded disk in @xmath326 with does not have local maxima for the distance to the origin of @xmath326 . thus a ribbon knot is slice , i.e. its @xmath10-genus is zero ; the long - standing slice - ribbon conjecture asks if the converse is true .",
    "[ theoreme sur le ribbon ] has been stated by lamm and also follows from his more general construction of ribbon symmetric unions ( [ la 2 ] , [ k - t ] ) .",
    "his proof is fairly allusive so we felt it would be useful to give a more detailed proof .",
    "+ we recall the well - known fact :    [ noeud symetrique est ribbon ] let @xmath327 be a knot in @xmath1 which is symmetric with respect to a plane @xmath164 in @xmath1 ; then it is ribbon .",
    "we endow @xmath1 with the frame @xmath11 and assume that @xmath164 is defined by the equation @xmath328 . by genericity arguments , we assume    1 .",
    "@xmath327 meets @xmath164 at a finite number of points 2 .   outside of @xmath164 ,",
    "@xmath327 is never tangent to the direction of @xmath329 .",
    "since @xmath327 has one component , it meets @xmath164 at exactly two points .",
    "+ we let @xmath330 ( resp .",
    "@xmath331 ) be the intersection of @xmath327 with the half - space of @xmath1 defined by @xmath332 ( resp .",
    "@xmath333 ) : @xmath330 and @xmath331 are both diffeomorphic to a closed interval",
    ". + letting @xmath334 be the symmetry in @xmath1 with respect to @xmath164 , we let @xmath335\\times k_+\\longrightarrow\\mathbb{r}^3\\ ] ] @xmath336 the self - intersections of @xmath337 are given by the data of @xmath338 such that @xmath339 we denote by @xmath340 , @xmath341 the coordinates of @xmath342 .",
    "since @xmath343 , ( [ egalite ] ) implies that @xmath344 thus the line segments @xmath345 and @xmath346 are both included in the line which is defined by the equations @xmath347 .",
    "moreover , one of them is included in the other one and we have a ribbon singularity .",
    "the main theorem tells us that , if @xmath34 and @xmath2 are mutually prime , with @xmath2 odd , @xmath6 is as in fig .",
    "[ premier dessin ] .",
    "+    [ h ]    [ deuxieme dessin ]    if @xmath3 is the number of strands , there are @xmath188 half - twist tangles connecting @xmath348 and @xmath349 ; we replace them by @xmath188 tangles and get the @xmath3-component link @xmath350 of fig .",
    "[ deuxieme dessin ] which is symmetric w.r.t . a plane .",
    "proposition [ noeud symetrique est ribbon ] tells us that @xmath350 bounds @xmath3 ribbon disks @xmath351 , ... , @xmath352 ; and",
    "the same arguments show us that two of these disks only have ribbon - type intersection .",
    "+ we now connect each @xmath353 to @xmath354 by a half - twisted band bounded by the half - twist tangle of fig .",
    "[ premier dessin ] .",
    "the resulting surface is a topological disk with only ribbon singularities .",
    "we use an idea by brandenbursky and kedra ( [ b - k ] ) .",
    "if @xmath355 is a @xmath3-braid , we denote by @xmath356 the link obtained by closing the braid @xmath355 . if @xmath357 and @xmath358 are @xmath3-two braids , [ b - k ] constructed a cobordism of euler characteristic @xmath359 between the closure of the product @xmath360 and the disjoint union of the closures @xmath361 .",
    "+ letting @xmath362 , @xmath363 , we recall that @xmath364 applying [ b - k ] s result @xmath9 times , we derive a cobordism in @xmath326 of euler characteristic @xmath365 between @xmath366 and @xmath367 .",
    "since @xmath368 is a ribbon knot ( theorem [ theoreme sur le ribbon ] ) , it bounds an embedded disk in @xmath326 .",
    "thus @xmath366 bounds a surface of euler characteristic @xmath369 we recover the formula ( [ inegalite pour le four genus ] ) for the genus and theorem [ theoreme sur le four - genus ] is proved .",
    "lee rudolph ( see [ ru ] for details ) defines a braid @xmath370 to be _ quasipositive _ if it is a product of conjugates @xmath371 of positive braid generators , i.e. @xmath372    [ rudolph]([ru ] ) if @xmath373 is a closed quasipositive braid written as in ( [ quasipositive ] ) closing in a knot @xmath374 , its four - genus verifies @xmath375    it is easy to check that under the assumptions of proposition [ four genus ; egalite ] , the exponents of all the @xmath376 s and @xmath377 s appearing respectively in @xmath56 and @xmath57 are all of the same sign . since we are working up to mirror symmetry",
    ", we can assume all these exponents to be equal to @xmath13 ; thus @xmath378 hence @xmath379 is a quasipositive braid ; theorem [ rudolph ] tells us that @xmath380 and proposition [ four genus ; egalite ] follows .",
    "we set @xmath381    [ forme",
    "de la tresse triviale ] @xmath382    the main thing to note about this formula is that all the positive generators are on one side and all the negative generators are on the other side .",
    "we use the main theorem .",
    "it assumes that @xmath2 is odd but in the present case , if @xmath2 is even , @xmath3 has to be odd , hence @xmath383 is odd and we switch @xmath2 and @xmath383 to apply the theorem .",

    "if @xmath391 is even , we let @xmath392    if @xmath393 is odd , we let @xmath394 in both cases , we check that the corresponding permutation between the endpoints of the braid is the identity , thus @xmath395 is a pure braid . +   + to prove that it is a trivial braid , we discuss when one strand of @xmath395 is above another one ; so let us fix some terminology .",
    "+ we number the strands of @xmath388 : the @xmath396-th strand , @xmath397 is the strand starting at the @xmath398-th point on the left ( the points being counted from top to bottom ) .",
    "+ we say that the @xmath396-th strand is above the @xmath96-th strand if , wherever there is a crossing point between these two strands , the @xmath396-th strand is above the @xmath96-th strand . as an exemple , in fig .",
    "[ second dessin ] , the red strand is above all the other strands .    [ au dessus de toutes les suivantes ] [ brins au dessus ]    if @xmath399 are two integers with @xmath400 , the @xmath396-th strand of @xmath395 is above the @xmath96-th strand .",
    "thus @xmath395 closes in @xmath3 unlinked trivial links , i.e. @xmath401 .    the figure [ second dessin ] illustrates the lemma .",
    "we describe the strands of @xmath395 in the braid shadow , i.e. their projection to the @xmath402 .",
    "we endow the plane with a coordinate @xmath403 such that the @xmath396-th strand starts at @xmath404 and ends at @xmath405 .",
    "the upper left point has coordinates @xmath406 ( in figure [ second dessin ] it is the starting point of the red strand ) .",
    "+ we say that a strand is _ ascending _ , denoted @xmath407 ( resp .",
    "_ descending _ , denoted @xmath408 ) if it has a @xmath94 ( resp .",
    "@xmath95 ) slope .",
    "it is _ horizontal _ , denoted @xmath409 , when the slope is @xmath41 .",
    "+   + we describe here the @xmath96-strands for @xmath96 odd ( the case of an even @xmath96 is similar ) : it goes up and down as follows +    1 .",

    "@xmath425 thus , if @xmath355 is the remainder of the division of @xmath426 by @xmath96 , we have @xmath427 the braid ( [ forme finale de la tresse triviale pour n pair ] ) is a piece of the braid @xmath428 where the @xmath269-th strand is above the @xmath396-th strands , for @xmath429 .",
    "thus the same is true for ( [ forme finale de la tresse triviale pour n pair ] ) which closes therefore in a trivial knot .",
    "this follows from the main theorem .",
    "we can also prove it directly by computing the crossing points and their sign : we see that every @xmath212 appears once and only once in the braid @xmath431 and so braid represents a trivial knot .",
    "we have now seen two cases where @xmath4 is trivial .",
    "we know that @xmath4 and @xmath432 are isotopic ; and @xmath433 and @xmath434 ( resp .",
    "@xmath435 ) are isotopic ( resp .",
    "mirror image of one another ) .",
    "thus we can get more examples of trivial knots , e.g. @xmath436 and @xmath437 .",
    "we give a better proof of the following fact from [ s - v ] :      without loss of generality , we assume @xmath442 . + if there is no critical phase ( i.e. a phase for which the knot is singular ) between @xmath438 and @xmath439 , the two knots are isotopic . + in [ s - v ] we showed that the difference between two critical phases is of the form      for two integers @xmath444 . +",
    "thus it is enough to prove that , for a given @xmath445 , and integers @xmath113 and @xmath114 , the knots @xmath446 and @xmath447 are the same or mirror images of one another .",
    "+ consider the parametrization of @xmath20 given in ( [ definition de la tresse ] ) ; we change its variable by setting @xmath448 and we rewrite the expression in ( [ definition de la tresse ] ) @xmath449 @xmath450 thus , if @xmath113 and @xmath114 have the same ( resp .",
    "opposite ) parities , the two knots are isotopic ( resp . mirror image of one another ) .",

  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> a point in the @xmath0-torus knot in @xmath1 goes @xmath2 times along a vertical circle while this circle rotates @xmath3 times around the vertical axis . in the lissajous - toric knot @xmath4 </S>",
    "<S> , the point goes along a vertical lissajous curve ( parametrized by @xmath5 while this curve rotates @xmath3 times around the vertical axis . </S>",
    "<S> such a knot has a natural braid representation @xmath6 which we investigate here . if @xmath7 , @xmath4 is ribbon ; if @xmath8 , @xmath6 is the @xmath9-th power of a braid which closes in a ribbon knot . </S>",
    "<S> we give an upper bound for the @xmath10-genus of @xmath4 in the spirit of the genus of torus knots ; we also give examples of @xmath4 s which are trivial knots . </S>"
  ]
}
